Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 09:21PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Nothing to be scared of. Your doctor is being thorough. I had a PET scan between surgery & chemo. It was mainly to be sure there weren't any hidden metastases .......That was NINE years ago! I think it's just an extra check to be sure you're clear -- glad I had it done.
Posts.Title: Meeting with BS yesterday Milane Hortense

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 06:49PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Not sure what you mean by one year follow up. Is this for a mammogram? Make your appointment! Get it checked out -- you might just have your mind set at ease. Many lumps -- hard or soft -- are benign. But any lump bears checking out on a regular basis. Perhaps a biopsy would even be in order if it has changed, grown or seems suspicious to your Dr.
Posts.Title: One year follow up crystalred7 crystalred7

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 05:20PM Optimistictraveler wrote: This really sounds like some sort of infection instead of breast cancer. And note that fibrocystic disease can be painful. Have some of the these symptoms appeared after you saw your doctor? (I ask this because you seemed to add some at the end.) New symptoms could point to other diagnoses. You should see your doctor again to determine exactly what is going on -- and what needs to be done for you to get better! Oh, and breathe.
Posts.Title: Very worried!!really need some advice please!!! Lisas1970 Lisas1970

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 09:08PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I know how worried you are about any delay -- I had the same concerns myself. I had to wait two weeks to see the surgeon, then another two weeks for stereotactic biopsy, then another two weeks for surgery & actually getting rid of the thing. Followed later by chemo after a 6-week wait for surgery site to heal. My BS & MO reassured me that the cancer is slow-growing & was probably growing over a period of several years before anything became noticeable (mine was found by mammogram, and although 2.7 cm. was not palpable by me or the surgeon). They both concurred that this sort of delay made no difference in the spread of my cancer. On the other hand, don't let them fob you off because of age & breastfeeding. (However, they will probably say having a great-grandmother with breast cancer doesn't increase your risk much, if any.) Do remember, that while far too many young women are dx'd with breast cancer, the odds are on your side that it's benign. Here's wishing you the best results when you do get checked out!
Posts.Title: Two week wait to see the doctor clbearr clbearr

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 09:05PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Footballnut, so sorry you have join us here. But it sounds like you are approaching this journey with a level head. Don't let anyone second-guess your treatment decisions. No cancer is exactly alike, just as no woman is exactly like another. Usually, the tumor size is just that - the tumor, not adding the lymph nodes. Often, even when there are cancer cells in the nodes, there is not a measurable tumor there. The staging is based on the size of the tumor & the number of nodes with cancer. Stage IV would include metastases beyond the breast & lymph nodes. About grandchildren: Â  When I was diagnosed, I also feared not living long enough to see any grandchildren. I didn't want to exert any pressure (only one of our three children was married or even in a steady relationship), so only my husband knew this. But about a year later, my son & daughter-in-law let us know they were expecting! They were really cute about telling us - they took us out for dinner to celebrate Mother's Day & gave me a small wrapped gift. I opened it to see a framed picture of the ultrasound! Took me a minute to realize what I was looking at.... Several months later, I cried (real tears, but tears of joy) on that early-morning drive to the hospital to await my first grandchild's birth! Now he is 7 years old, an active (and smart) first-grader, and I also have three granddaughters added to the mix! (I still need to see my youngest son married & starting a family.)
Posts.Title: Positive nodes with long term survival many Lily55

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2013 08:24PM - edited Oct 10, 2013 08:25PM by Optimistictraveler Good advice here. Remember that cancer is survivable, as many of us can attest to. My husband took the duty of calling our grown kids to tell them, as well as his parents. I was afraid I would break into tears trying to tell them, and didn't want to upset them any more than the facts would. I told my Mom myself by telephone (she lived 7 hours away). Soon after, the shock wore off and I felt better about the diagnosis & became pretty strong emotionally. I was and determined to fight this beast with all I had! Guess that worked, because it's been more than 9 years since my diagnosis. Actually, sounds better to say that I'm into the 10th year!
Posts.Title: 45 yr old found a 3cmx1.5cm AnnieeC Janet456

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2013 08:43PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I had genetic testing -- after I had completed the majority of my treatment. My grandmother died of BC when I was very young, and my uncle died of colon cancer -- I found out this family history sometimes is related to BRAC1 or BRAC2. I do know that the genetic incidence of BC is very low, as far as we know at this point. Then, a woman I knew found out after mets that she was positive for BRAC (and had young children). She was not in one of the groups at high risk of BRAC1 or 2. I decided to get the testing for the sake of my daughter, and my grandchildren. Found out I am negative, but I feel it is good to know for sure whether positive or negative. If positive, you will approach treatment much differently, possibly having ovaries removed in addition to MX, and possibly follow more aggressive treatment overall. And other close family members might do the same.
Posts.Title: Clinic just called and now want genetic testing tekwriter Optimistictraveler

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2013 08:57PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I'm working on the 10 years -- 9+ so far (NED), so nearly there. I'm also triple positive (ER+, PR+, Her2+). I'm doing great, still on Arimidex after almost 9 years. Hope this gives hope to others.
Posts.Title: Stage III Cancer Survivors .... 10+ Years and Out AlwaysHope karen1956

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 11:24PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I had no symptoms at all, no palpable lump (even the BS couldn't find it). BC was found on mammogram - although I was at that point having them every 6 months. I only wish biopsy had been offered earlier instead of more frequent mammos - it might have been found at a smaller, less invasive stage.
Posts.Title: Did you have any symptoms prior to being diagnosed? Footballnut Footballnut

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2013 01:52PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Probably scar tissue. I have scar tissue from a biopsy I had long ago (benign), and also scar tissue from my lumpectomy 12 years later, different area but cancerous. The sites of both surgeries do feel like lumpy bumps, but are perfectly normal. Now, when I have a mammogram, they put "markers" on the scars (zigzag tape with metal wire in it) so they know that what shows up there is the scarring. Probably your doctor will put your fears to rest when you see him/her tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy (1 week ago today) always_smile21 always_smile21

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2013 10:57PM - edited Oct 10, 2013 10:59PM by Optimistictraveler I think whether a lump is palpable or not is not always dependent on size of the lump, but also on location & the structure of your breasts (dense or fibrous breast vs. not dense). A "deep" mass may not always be palpable. I would recommend talking to your doctor -- hopefully one who specializes in breast cancer surgery -- to see if you can at least get a biopsy before the scheduled date. Perhaps a stereotactic biopsy? With a sterotactic biopsy, the imaging will guide the surgeon in placement of the needle for biopsy, especially valuable for a non-palpable mass.
Posts.Title: Solid mass seen but not felt. Gcramer1110

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2013 10:58PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Techs usually aren't allowed to tell you anything. And until the radiologist reads it, no one suggests a biopsy (at least to my knowledge). "Suspicious" only means something should be looked at -- many, many times it turns out to be benign. And with fibrocystic breast disease and dense breast tissue, this is not unusual -- be glad your medical specialists are being extra thorough. It's difficult to wait, we all know, but really, that's all you can do now. Try not to worry, and certainly don't jump to a "worst case" scenario. We all send our hopes & prayers that everything is benign, but remember that there are lots of us around many years after a BC diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Worried and Waiting.... Krisea scaredmamaof5

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 11:09PM - edited Nov 26, 2013 11:11PM by Optimistictraveler I, too, take offense at the OP's diatribe against modern medicine. I was diagnosed with an aggressive Stage III BC (with lymph node involvement) more than 9 years ago. Prior to this, I had known some women who didn't survive more than 3 or 4 years after diagnosis. My own grandmother survived only 5 years after double mx many, many years ago, before chemo & radiation treatments for BC (I'm negative for BRAC1 & 2). I feel that the only reason I am here now, still alive, is due to the advances of modern medicine -- and the dedication of my involved, caring treatment team. Every part of my treatment plan was geared to giving me the longest, healthiest lifetime I could have. The difficult times of surgery, chemotherapy & other treatments were just brief moments in my active life, and totally worth it.
Posts.Title: Don't make rush decision based on doctors urgency Ogicam ziggypop

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2014 10:58PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Last year, I had severe radiating pain down my right leg (sciatica). My PCP put it down to "muscle strain," but as time went on, it didn't get any better & I starting worrying about the possibility of mets.Â  Finally, after several more visits to Dr., the PA that saw me last decided I should have an MRI. This after four excruciating months! Can't tell how really happy I was to find out that I had three herniated discs - but no mets! I'm much better now, and without surgery (spinal injections a couple of times, exercises & hanging upside down), so glad!Â Funny how your point of view changes!
Posts.Title: Bone Scan - 2/20 Kicks pupfoster1

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2013 02:38PM - edited Dec 10, 2013 02:39PM by Optimistictraveler I only had one site that needed biopsy, but if I had more, I would definitely have wanted all of them biopsied! Oh, and my mass was also not palpable, only found on mammogram. Doing it on the same day certainly makes sense to me -- would you want have the first biopsy done, then come back to take another day or 1/2 day for second biopsy? Try to not be scared -- just be glad your radiologist is being thorough. My cancer was in an area that for several years, I repeatedly had to come back for a closer look or ultrasound, but was still not deemed a serious concern. I'm pretty sure that's when the tumor was (looking in retrospect at old mammograms, branching calcifications & a mass were evident even to me). Maybe if the biopsy had been done earlier, my cancer would have been found before it grew to 2.7cm & spread to 5 lymph nodes!
Posts.Title: Two different biopsies? pegasus68 awb

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2013 12:48AM - edited Oct 9, 2013 12:50AM by Optimistictraveler I lost about 10 pounds in total,but unfortunately put it back on after chemo was over. Now, much later, I've taken off about 15 from where I started pre-chemo. That put my blood sugar back in the normal range, instead of pre diabetic. While on chemo, I couldn't tolerate a lot of foods. Taste buds went wonky, plus mouth sores made it worse. Appetite was depressed, too, but I knew I needed to eat to keep up strength & fight this beast. And I did drink plenty of water. Macaroni & cheese, scrambled eggs & English muffins with a little butter & jam were the mainstays of my diet. I would make a recipe of mac & cheese (packaged, horrors!), refrigerate the potful, then scoop some out & reheat in microwave when I felt a little hungry. I also ate the pre-packaged lunch pack puddings, fruits & jello. Couldn't tolerate wine or soda at all. Only rarely had coffee or tea (had been a caffeine addict!) My sister-in-law was being kind & sent care packages of Godiva chocolates, which sadly, I hardly ate. They didn't taste like anything to me -- but hubby was really appreciative & helped with making them disappear! The worst was when I was on AC. Later in treatment, when I was on Taxol, appetite & taste buds recovered somewhat. At least it was only a couple of months.
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2013 08:53PM - edited Sep 30, 2013 08:54PM by Optimistictraveler Yes, it's nerve-wracking. Waiting is always so difficult. We always want the answers right away, even if it's bad -- and that's probably what we all think at first!Â  I just want you to know we are all here for you, whenever you need it. We've all been there -- but we're still around to talk about it! Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: The Wait is the Worst Sam2U mermaid18

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 04:32PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Being more concerned won't help. 80% of the times that someone is referred for biopsy after mammogram, results are benign. Your radiologist is just being prudent in ordering followup. Don't try to decipher or read too much into it. And yes, even if it's cancer, the lump being very small & no lymph node involvement are both good signs that it would be at an early stage. At this point, all you can do is relax & get through the next few days. Best wishes to you, hoping for benign!
Posts.Title: Concerns ktlearn keepthefaith

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2013 11:14PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Keep in mind that most breast cancers grow very slowly. My docs said mine had probably been there for 4 or 5 years, maybe even more. Three months delay will probably not make much difference (if any), even if it's cancer.
Posts.Title: They biopsied the wrong place Librarian Optimistictraveler

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 02:28AM Optimistictraveler wrote: The reddened area should definitely be checked. I had abscesses at two different times during chemo, one in the lumpectomy incision area, and another in the axillary node incision area. Since chemo zaps your body's ability to fight off even minor infection, that infection can escalate pretty quickly into abscess. Redness of the skin that got larger day to day was one of the signs I had, as well as systemic illness (fever, etc.) I had never had an abscess before - so didn't really recognize what it was at first.
Posts.Title: Big tumor.. Need advice! art133 Oceana

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 10:16PM Optimistictraveler wrote: When I get a mammogram, they are very careful to clearly mark any scars, etc. on my breasts -- so that they are aware it's something that was already there & they knew about. They use little bits of zigzag sticky tape with a wire in the middle that shows up on the mammo. Is the injury actually in the breast area? While I don't know if anything will show up on mammogram, I would definitely mention it to the mammogram tech beforehand.Â
Posts.Title: question about recent injury to ribs and mammogram debmc1958 debmc1958

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 02:59AM Optimistictraveler wrote: Get it checked out. It could be infection instead of cancer - but should be checked ASAP anyway. Does she have a BC dx? Large tumor? Or is that just a supposition? If she has already been dx's with BC, she should see her medical oncologist and/or breast surgeon.
Posts.Title: Big tumor.. Need advice! art133 Oceana

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2013 07:43PM Optimistictraveler wrote: <"they took the biopsy of the wrong mass"> Perhaps there was more than one mass? The phrasing here sounds like it to me -- and maybe there is another area of concern that didn't get biopsied. Sometimes this is the case -- and the area that was actually biopsied was B9. The clip that was placed will signal to them an area that was OK. I'm assuming that whatever was biopsied was sent to pathology -- have you gotten the B9 diagnosis on that yet?
Posts.Title: They biopsied the wrong place Librarian Optimistictraveler

Posts.Content: May 14, 2014 10:38PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I would add that offering transportation or support for scans, procedures or treatment sessions is helpful. A good friend drove me to the hospital for my sentinel node mapping & stayed with me for the entire time. For some procedures, the patient shouldn't drive due to the effect of certain medications - and having a friend there while waiting is always a help! My friend also brought meals for several days after my surgery. (Unfortunately, she didn't offer housecleaning or laundry & I didn't ask....but hubby took care of that.) Do ask if she needs help with any errands or shopping, or taking the kids to sports practice or dance class (etc.) if they are at that age. I would say that the #1 thing to AVOID is telling her about the people you know about who had cancer & are fine now (or even worse, NOT fine!) Â I can't count how many times people said that to me! Maybe the ones they knew had stage 0 or stage 1. I was at stage 3, grade 3, triple positive - and just hearing that "somebody" is still OK 20 years after cancer, well, that just didn't help me feel positive about the outcome. Make specific offers to help, be a good friend & sounding board, and just "be there" for her. You are so kind & compassionate to want to reach out & help her at this time - she is blessed to have a new friend like you.
Posts.Title: Giving support, what is the most helpful? jamiemarlowe busymama

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 10:02PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Chemotherapy is not a walk in the park, but it is not nearly as bad as the movies make it out to be. Some people actually have a pretty easy time of it - depends a lot on the individual person and also on exactly what chemotherapy agents you will be given. Some people even carry on working their regular jobs & keeping Â up household duties! I worked part-time during chemo, but had very little energy. However, I think some of the newer chemo regimens might be easier (mine was nearly 10 years ago). I also had "does-dense" chemo protocol, which means that I had treatment every two weeks instead of three weeks - this is probably more difficult than every three weeks. There are medications to reduce or eliminate nausea - these are often given as an IV alongside the chemo, plus tablets to be used as needed (or IF needed) in the weeks between treatments. So the intractable vomiting shown is movies just isn't current-day reality (if it ever was). And there are treatments for many of the other side effects you might experience. My MO's office told me to call if I had ANY problems (fever, pain, mouth sores, etc.) & at least talk to the call nurse. Usually, they had some medication available to help out. I had NO side effects on Herceptin (weekly treatments for a year).
Posts.Title: Whirlwind... Terri001 Rmanmom

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 10:48PM - edited Mar 13, 2014 10:58PM by Optimistictraveler I started chemo in Oct. 2004. My MO went to the Breast Cancer Symposium in Dec. 2004 (he goes every year), when reports came out that the stage III trials of Herceptin for adjuvant treatment were stopped because researchers felt results indicated so strongly that Herceptin stopped the cancer in its tracks (my words) - that it would be unethical to withhold Herceptin from those in the control group who were getting placebo. Â Prior to this, Herceptin was only used in cases of metastasic Her2+ BC. (I may be getting this a little wrong, but it's the gist of what he told me.) So, my MO said I would get Herceptin early on - starting at the tail end of Taxol. And my insurance paid for it! While I would be most happy not to have had cancer at all, I'm so glad that it came along at this point in my life, not a few years earlier! I feel that Herceptin is likely what has saved me - I knew several women who were dx'd shortly before I was, and they died within 3-4 years of dx.Â  I have been on Arimidex since about May 2005. No side effects from that, either - just another pill I have to take. My MO & I discussed it, and I will probably continue on it as long as my bone density is still OK when I get the Dexa in June.
Posts.Title: Whirlwind... Terri001 Rmanmom

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 06:56PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Each stage of my diagnosis took about 2 weeks or so. After a "bad" mammogram, it took about 2 weeks to see the surgeon, then 2 weeks for the biopsy. (Results of the biopsy only took about 3 or 4 days - the surgeon called me.) Second surgery took another two weeks, for final staging.Â  My surgeon did not remove all lymph nodes. He performed what is called a "sentinel node biopsy." Dye was injected before surgery, that would show the lymph nodes nearest to the breast during surgery. These sentinel nodes are first in line to any further on, so if they are clear, there is no cancer further up the chain.Those sentinel nodes were examined by the pathologist during surgery & looked OK on first exam. If they are all clear, no further surgery is necessary. But in my case, further examination by the pathologist (after the original quick look during surgery) showed cancer in four out of the five sentinel nodes. So, I had to have a later surgery for my surgeon to remove more lymph nodes further up the chain. I had a total of 21 lymph nodes removed with cancer in 5 of them.Â

Just click on the box at the top "Start a new topic." Maybe use a title like "Worried - several small lumps suddenly appeared". You will probably get better answers this way.
Posts.Title: wondering if I should be worried? vera82 Optimistictraveler

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 10:57PM Optimistictraveler wrote: My breast surgeon did mine, but if I recall, the radiologist was also in attendance. I felt very comfortable with this situation because I already knew the surgeon. He had done my B9 biopsy 10 years earlier, plus I had consulted him this time as soon as I had "bad" mammogram results. He also did a fine needle biopsy in the office prior to the stereotactic biopsy that was a week or so later. I didn't know the radiologist at all.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy Star13 cactus

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2013 08:54PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Odds are that it is unrelated to your cancer or to the Arimidex. Could easily be a bursitis or similar injury -- just because we've had cancer or are taking Arimidex (or similar) doesn't mean we won't get ordinary, non-related aches & pains. My recommendation is to see your doctor to get it checked out. You might want to start with your oncologist, just to be on the safe side. And some women have taken a little vacation from hormonals just to see if it suddenly clears up when off the med.
Posts.Title: Shoulder pain in noncancer side Rachel1 hopefour

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 06:35PM Optimistictraveler wrote: Don't get ahead of yourself! And don't jump to conclusions about what the report says. That is a sure way to get freaked out! There is a lot of technical "jargon" in the report, that you don't know what it signifies. Until someone explains the pathology report to you, you don't really know how "bad" it is. (So try to relax as much as you can!) I did not have any staging, size, hormone receptor information or much else after my biopsy - except that it was cancer. Â I had to wait until a couple of weeks after the lumpectomy for all the pathology reports, etc.Â
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 06:39PM Optimistictraveler wrote: The tumor markers give a baseline number, it doesn't have to be 0. If the number rises considerably from the baseline, then the dr. would be concerned & order scans & other followup tests to see if there is a recurrence or metastasis. Some doctors think the tumor markers are too vague & don't even order them. My MO orders them every 6 months - good for all these years (almost 10).
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2013 08:08PM Optimistictraveler wrote: And the pain you are describing is not a typical symptom or sign of breast cancer. But do get it checked out -- could be something else entirely.
Posts.Title: Im only 22 years old annlove12 Optimistictraveler

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2014 09:12PM Optimistictraveler wrote: I had a PET scan done - after the sentinel node biopsy showed cancer in 4 out of 5 nodes. I'm not sure they would have done it if the nodes were all negative. But once they know the cancer has escaped to the lymph nodes, I think they want to be sure it hasn't gone further than that! Â I believe the PET scan is best to show active cancer elsewhere in the body (better than CT) but they don't necessarily do it if lymph nodes are clear. I did have further surgery after that - more lymph node dissection plus a re-incision at the lumpectomy to get wider margins. They found cancer in one more lymph node, but nothing further up the chain. Mind you, all this was almost TEN (10) years ago. I had stage III, grade 3 (aggressive), triple positive Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, 2.7 cm. tumor, with involvement in 5 lymph nodes. And here I am all these years later, NED (No Evidence of Disease). It's a tough journey, but one you can manage - with a good outcome afterwards!
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone
